history.content:
Axler was what we used to learn Math 110 when I took it. I think that this book is really good for self-study since it does a lot of handholding for a lot of the proofs that are presented, and it has some good exercises. You will realize that there is indeed a lot of overlap between Math 54 and Math 110. The main difference is HOW the material is presented. In Math 110, the material is presented in a more abstract/generalized way. This will become useful for when you start to cover more advanced theorems like SVD, Jordan Canonical form etc.

One thing that I didn't like about Axler is that it downplayed (a little too much) the role of determinants in linear algebra.

Axler was what we used to learn Math 110 when I took it. I think that this book is really good for self-study since it does a lot of handholding for a lot of the proofs that are presented, and it has some good exercises. You will realize that there is indeed a lot of overlap between Math 54 and Math 110. The main difference is HOW the material is presented. In Math 110, the material is presented in a more abstract/generalized way. This is useful for when you start to cover more advanced theorems like SVD, Jordan Canonical form etc.

One thing that I didn't like about Axler is that it downplayed (a little too much) the role of determinants in linear algebra.

I want to learn the 110 material because I wasn't able to get into the class (and I have a lecture conflict now so i can't audit it either). 

1. Is working through Axler's sufficient to learn the 110 material. I know theres a different textbook but I already have a copy of Axler's and I really like his style.

2. If not, what resources should I use if I want to learn linear algebra beyond math 54?

Edit: I saw Soroush mentioned that Axler would be useful to self-study. I was wondering if someone could explain why since from skimming through it, it doesn't seem like Axler's goes much deeper than the 54 textbook.
history.subject: Using Axler's to self-study math 110
